The year when Utah authorities began searching for Rossi through a decade-old DNA rape kit, leading to his identification and subsequent legal actions.

keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man from Rhode Island, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008 and sentenced to between five years and life in prison.
Rossi allegedly faked his death in 2020, with an online obituary falsely claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which authorities later debunked.
He fled the U.S. and was arrested in Scotland in 2021, identified through distinctive tattoos and an Interpol notice, and extradited to Utah in January 2024.
Rossi used multiple aliases, including Arthur Knight, and has a history of evading justice, including being previously wanted in Rhode Island for failing to register as a sex offender.
The victim in the first case described a pattern of financial manipulation and abuse, including asking her to pay for dates, lend money, and take on debt for engagement rings.
He was convicted in two separate cases in August and September 2025, with sentencing in the first case occurring on October 20, 2025, and the second scheduled for November 4, 2025.
Utah law allows prison sentences for rape to be given as a range (five years to life), with a parole board determining release.
Rossi denied the charges during trial and maintained his innocence, stating 'I am not guilty of this. These women are lying.'

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Utah judge sentenced Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man who allegedly faked his death in 2020 to evade arrest on rape charges, to a prison term of between five years and life in prison. Rossi, whose legal name is Nicholas Alahverdian, was identified in 2018 through a DNA match from a decade-old rape kit. After being falsely reported as deceased via an online obituary, he fled the U.S. and was arrested in Scotland in 2021 based on distinctive tattoos and an Interpol notice. He was extradited to Utah in January 2024 and convicted in two separate cases involving rapes in northern Utah in 2008. The victim in the first case described a pattern of manipulation and abuse, including financial exploitation and coercive control. Rossi, a known flight risk and serial abuser, used multiple aliases, including Arthur Knight, to evade justice and was previously wanted in Rhode Island for failing to register as a sex offender. The case underscores the dangers of predatory behavior, the importance of DNA backlog efforts, and the resilience of justice systems in tracking fugitives.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
